objinfo.printdate: 1795The characteristics of the color printing indicate that this impression is the first one printed in 1795. The second impression in this printing is *Lamech and His Two Wives* in the Tate Collection (Butlin 297).
objinfo.objsize: 37.8 x 47.5 cm.The considerably larger impression now in the Tate Collection (Butlin 297) indicates that this example was trimmed on all four sides, most severely on the right and left margins.
objinfo.medium: planographic color printing with water color and pen and ink additions to the impression

provenance.name: Collection of Robert N. Essick
provenance.note: Inherited by Blake's wife Catherine upon his death in 1827; acquired by Frederick Tatham upon the death of Catherine Blake in 1831; possibly the dealer Joseph Hogarth in the first half of the nineteenth century; unrecorded collector or collectors; acquired by Joseph Whitwell Pease (1828-1903) by the second half of the nineteenth century; bequeathed in 1903 to Miss S. H. Pease; the executor of her estate, Lord Wardington; offered Christie's, 2 Dec. 1938, lot 59 (bought-in by Lady Wardington); by descent in the family of Lady Wardington; offered Sotheby's, 28 Nov. 1974, lot 136 (bought-in at £3500, but acquired immediately after the auction by the Oxfordshire book dealer Colin Franklin); purchased from Franklin by Robert N. Essick, May 1975 ($30,000). The varnish was removed from the work and the print was repaired and conserved in 1994.

desc.objtitle: Lamech and His Two Wives, Object 1 (Butlin 298)

objnote.p: The subject of "Lamech and His Two Wives" is derived from Genesis 4:23-4. Lamech, a descendent of Cain and the central figure in the design, has in a rage killed the young man lower right. Lamech clutches his head in despair and in the knowledge that the penalty of Cain will fall on him "seventy and sevenfold" (Genesis 4:24). Lamech's two wives, Adah and Zillah, cling together on the left. Blake may have known the more detailed telling of the story in the Apocrypha, as well as the traditional association between Lamech's son, Tubalcain, and metal working.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The central figure, Lamech, holds his head in distress as he stares at the dead body lying on the ground to the right. His two wives, Adah and Zillah, stand to the left of Lamech, embracing each other as they look toward their husband. A flowing piece of drapery, perhaps part of a tent, descends along the left margin of the design. The background is mountainous and dark, with a dark cloud upper right. The ground is covered in low vegetation (grass, moss, or lichens?).

component.illusobjdesc: Lamech, the central figure, pulls at his hair with clenched hands. His upper arms are extended horizontally from his body, with elbows bent and his lower arms reaching upward to his head. He stares to the right at the dead body on the ground with a facial expression of despair and agony. He has short (?) hair and a long beard. His left foot is prominent at the hem of his flowing gown. As he faces the viewer, he stands with his torso twisting slightly to the right.

Adah and Zillah, Lamech's two wives, embrace each other as they stand to the left of Lamech. The woman on the left has long, flowing hair, curly where it falls over her right shoulder. She is gowned, but her right shoulder and arm are bare. Her right arm is under the other woman’s left arm and wrapped around the second woman’s waist. Her left arm must be similarly wrapped around the other side of the woman’s torso, for her left hand rests along the other woman's side just below the right hand, which lies over, or is holding, the left wrist. It seems that her left hand is clutching the gown. She faces forward but twists to the right. Her facial expression suggests sorrow or melancholy; her eyes appear to be looking into the distance rather than at Lamech or the dead man.

Adah and Zillah, Lamech's two wives, embrace each other as they stand to the left of Lamech. The woman on the right has long, flowing hair. She appears to be gowned from the hips to her feet. Her left arm is over the other woman’s right arm, embracing her hip. Although colored the same as the other woman's gown, we can see the outline of her right hand just under and below her left. Thus, her right arm must also be wrapped around the woman on the left. We see the woman on the right from behind, but her face is twisted sharply to right profile. She appears to be looking at Lamech.

Lower right is a muscular dead male lying prone on the ground. His arms are sprawled outward parallel to the ground in a cruciform position. His left arm is cut off by the trimmed edge of the image. His right hand, palm down, is prominently pictured left of Lamech's lower legs. The dead man appears to be nude with short, curly hair.
Along the left margin of the design there appears to be a piece of flowing drapery that may be the side of a tent.
The mounds in the foreground, with perhaps a low hill just right of the legs of the embracing women, are covered in grass, moss, lichens, or some such low vegetation.
Dark mountains rise in the background. Above the mountains upper right is a dark, stormy cloud that darkens the surrounding sky.
